{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3556811,"name":"","username":"RobotMaker","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/r/8e8cbc/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-03-14T06:01:06.135Z","cooked":"

Hi,

We use swerve-drive with YAGSL. At last comp, we hit an issue a few times: When auto started, the robot struggled and often didn’t move on the first pathfinder segment (we can see in Advantage Scope recording that the wheels were trying to rotate, but two of them seemed to sometimes get a bit stuck). Sometimes the issue goes away after a few seconds or when the second path filter segment begins.

After trying many things, we finally tried diagnosing the issue using YAGSL’s SwerveDriveTest class, using setAngleSysIdRoutine().. This test-routine can be used to test the angular motors by turning the wheels clockwise 20+ times while increasing motor voltage from 0-5 over several seconds. Basically, the wheels all rotate clockwise for a few secs (i.e. sweeping from pointing North to pointing East to pointing South to pointing West - in a smooth circle - repeat 20x)

.
We got a repro this evening of the BackLeft and FrontRight wheels seemingly getting “stuck” when voltage was applied:

I’ve attached a snapshot of the results we got when recording the voltage and angular rotation position for one of the broken wheels (BACKLEFT) in PURPLE. I’ve also shown in YELLOW one of the 2 wheels that is behavior well for comparison, to show that its voltage is increasing very steadily from 0-5v.

Screenshot 2025-03-13 at 10.57.51 PM2076×1091 254 KB

Any ideas? By the way, I ran this test 3 times. 2 times the wheels misbehaved. Then I rebooted our robot and ran again and all 4 wheels worked great in this swerve test. Ug.

Additional info about our motors:
Turn: spark max +neo
Drive: Neo vortex +flex motor controller

I’d check your current limits and current draw - there aren’t many other things that can cause a linear voltage ramp to output wrongly like this.

","post_number":3,"post_type":1,"posts_count":5,"updated_at":"2025-03-14T15:11:31.592Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":2,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":23,"readers_count":22,"score":4.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":495543,"topic_slug":"backleft-and-frontright-swerve-drive-angular-motors-occasionally-get-stuck-for-a-few-seconds","display_username":"Eli Barnett","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":59276,"username":"RobotMaker","name":"","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/r/8e8cbc/{size}.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":12381,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Robot apartments! invisible suburbs! skeleton treasuries!"},"post_url":"/t/backleft-and-frontright-swerve-drive-angular-motors-occasionally-get-stuck-for-a-few-seconds/495543/3","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3557191,"name":"Rahul Yarlagadda","username":"Knufire","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/knufire/{size}/67820_2.png","created_at":"2025-03-14T18:25:33.741Z","cooked":"

I wouldn’t rule out a hardware issue either. Make sure there a loose fastener, backwards bearing, etc on the modules that may be causing high amounts of friction at certain points in the rotation.

If you have the time and spare motors/controllers, swapping them out might be worth it just to rule it out as a potential cause.

It seems like you’ve created a really robust test here and the inconsistency in the behavior generally makes me lean away from this being a software issue.

","post_number":4,"post_type":1,"posts_count":5,"updated_at":"2025-03-14T18:26:47.121Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":12,"readers_count":11,"score":17.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":495543,"topic_slug":"backleft-and-frontright-swerve-drive-angular-motors-occasionally-get-stuck-for-a-few-seconds","display_username":"Rahul Yarlagadda","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":12760,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"7457 Mentor"},"post_url":"/t/backleft-and-frontright-swerve-drive-angular-motors-occasionally-get-stuck-for-a-few-seconds/495543/4","reactions":[{"id":"point_up","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3557203,"name":"Adam Fleming","username":"AdamF","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/adamf/{size}/234717_2.png","created_at":"2025-03-14T18:45:42.777Z","cooked":"

I would also agree this seems to be a hardware issue assuming you are using the default YAGSL angle current limit (I think it’s 20A?). Did you change the current limits? It would be useful to plot current as well as voltage to see if you are hitting the current limit and what the limit is.

Concerning the modules:

  1. What modules are you using?
  2. How much use have they seen?
  3. Have they been greased properly?
  4. If you rotate them by hand with power disconnect, do the problem modules have more resistance then the others?
